list_page_teaser: American Presidents, just like any other group of individuals, have different personalities.  Learn how the images of some popular and recent presidents reflect their idealism, decisiveness, and other qualities.
description_html:
Which politicians – ☺ if any ☺ – are your favorites? How does your personality compare to theirs?

This gallery contains a few spiritual portraits of our presidents from the 1900s. If you know your four-letter type, perhaps you can see similarities between your personality and that of your favorite president — assuming you have one!
story_html:
I frequently wonder whether an individual's personality type has any bearing on how they lean politically. As an idealist, I am definitely biased toward idealistic presidents, such as Jefferson and Lincoln.

If this topic interests you, check out David Keirsey's book Presidential Temperament. It covers this topic in depth!

I will be adding portraits to this gallery soon. To keep up to date and learn when I post new images, follow this site on social media or join the SeeOurMinds.com email list!

image_list.gallery_page_teaser: Ronald Reagan's spiritual portrait shows he is very rational and slightly idealistic.  Click on the image to learn more!
image_list.explain_dom: The Green in Ronald Reagan's spiritual portrait represents his dominant personality trait, his preference for making rational rather than personal decisions.  In Extraverts, the dominant trait is directed outwardly, and spiritual portraits use a long vertical line to represent this, because it is the side of their personality that is most evident.  He demonstrated this trait when he told 11,345 striking air traffic controllers to return to work within 48 hours, and fired them when they refused to do so.
image_list.explain_aux: The Blue in Ronald Reagan's spiritual portrait represents his auxiliary personality trait, his very slight preference for seeing the world more in terms of ideas than of facts.  In Extraverts, the auxiliary trait is directed inwardly, and spiritual portraits use a horizontal line to represent this.  He demonstrated this trait when he came up with the Stratigic Defense Initiative, in his deeply held Christian beliefs, and in the way he delegated many of the details in the day-to-workings of the White House to his subordinates.
image_list.story_intro_html:
Born in Tampico, Illinois on February 6, 1911, Ronald Wilson Reagan became the 40th President at the age of 69 in 1981. Even though Reagan was born two years before Richard Nixon, he became president more than a decade after Nixon.

Governor Reagan

Before being elected President in 1980, Ronald Reagan served two terms as Governor of California, from 1967 to 1975.

Entering office as the 33rd Governor of California, he replaced the 32nd Governor Pat Brown, who had served two terms from 1959-1967. After Reagan served his two terms, Pat's son Jerry Brown entered the office as the 34th Governor and also served two terms, from 1975-1983.

As the large amounts of Green in their spiritual portraits show, presidents Reagan and Nixon had similar personalities. And as the other colors show — Reagan's Blue as opposed to Nixon's Yellow in particular — there were differences.

Anti-Communist, and Law-and-Order Candidate

After serving first in the Army Reserve, then later in the Army Air Forces during World War II, Reagan caught up in the anti-communist fervor that prevailed in the United States in the late 1940s and early 1950s. As President of the Screen Actors Guild from 1947 through 1959, Reagan's politics caused him to lose his first wife and meet his second one in 1949.

In 1969 Ronald Reagan was Governor of California during the violent protests at People's Park in Berkeley. As his fellow Republican Richard Nixon did when running for President in 1968, Reagan leveraged this distruption by campaigning as a law-and-order candidate in his campaign for re-election in 1970.

Peacemaker

Ronald Reagan's anti-communist, law-and-order stance does not imply he was an enemy of peace.

As the Green in his spiritual portrait shows, Ronald Reagan preferred logic to emotion. So although both he and the protesters wanted peace, he differed from them in that he was not inclined to get all emotional about it.

I believe with all my heart that our first priority must be world peace, and that use of force is always and only a last resort, when everything else has failed, and then only with regard to our national security.
 — Ronald Reagan, in his presidential debate with Jimmy Carter, October 28, 1980.

In the A Time for Choosing speech Reagan gave supporting Barry Goldwater in 1964, he quotes Alexander Hamilton, Patrick Henry, and Winston Churchill in explaining that Goldwater desired not just peace, but peace through strength.

Crisis: Iran-Contra

In the presidential election of 1984, Ronald Reagan carried all but one state. Like many other two-term presidents, he fell prey to the second-term curse, a superstition that may betray a tendency towards confirmation bias. In Reagan's case, the curse did indeed come true, at least to a certain extent.

Ronald Reagan believed the forces behind democracy and freedom were stronger than those behind communism and tyranny. In a speech given at the Annual Dinner of the Conservative Political Action Conference (CPAC) on March 1, 1985 he declared that the freedom fighters in Nicaragua — known as the contras — were the moral equal of our Founding Fathers and the brave men and women of the French Resistance.

Reagan wanted to support the Nicaraguan rebels, but Congress had passed the Boland Amendment forbidding it. Unbeknownst to Reagan, his administration had been involved in diverting funds from arms sales to Iran to the contras in Nicaragua.

As the Blue in his spiritual portrait shows, Reagan embraced ideals — religious and patriotic ideals, specifically. As a result, he was an optimist, and it was difficult for him to believe that people in his administration had been breaking the law by diverting funds to the contras.

Reagan's Idealism Backfires

As reports of the arms for hostages deals started to appear in Arab newspapers, reporters in America began pressuring Reagan for answers. Reagan responded by appearing on national television and addressing the issue in what he, at that time, thought was a direct way:

The charge has been made that the United States has shipped weapons to Iran as ransom payment for the release of American hostages in Lebanon, that the United States undercut its allies and secretly violated American policy against trafficking with terrorists. Those charges are utterly false.... We did not — repeat — did not trade weapons or anything else for hostages, nor will we.
 — Ronald Reagan in an Address to the Nation on the Iran Arms and Contra Aid Controversy, November 13, 1986.

Over the next few weeks, the people responsible for the clandestine deals were identified. By the end of November, John Poindexter, Reagan's National Security Advisor, had resigned, and Reagan had fired Oliver North, who was one of the main people behind the malfeasance.

Lax Managerial Style

As time went on and more information surfaced, Ronald Reagan's popularity dropped precipitously, and he began to see past his idealism. Eventually he realized the truth lingering on the other side of his rose-colored glasses.

Amid references to parallels with Richard Nixon's Watergate scandal, on December 1, 1986 Ronald Reagan created the Tower Commission to investigate the matter.

A few months ago I told the American people I did not trade arms for hostages. My heart and my best intentions still tell me that's true, but the facts and the evidence tell me it is not. As the Tower board reported, what began as a strategic opening to Iran deteriorated, in its implementation, into trading arms for hostages. This runs counter to my own beliefs, to administration policy, and to the original strategy we had in mind. There are reasons why it happened, but no excuses. It was a mistake.
 — Ronald Reagan in an Address to the Nation on the Iran Arms and Contra Aid Controversy, March 4, 1987.

The commission's report cleared Reagan of wrong-doing, but chastised him for not being fully aware of what people working for him were actually doing. If he was guilty of anything, it was of having a lax managerial style.

Ending the Cold War

While this was going on, Ronald Reagan was meeting with Mickhail Gorbachev, the General Secretary of the Soviet Union. Of particular concern were:

  • The Berlin Wall, both an imposing physical barrier and symbolic icon of the Cold War, and
  • The possibility of Nuclear War, which posed a very real threat to all life on the planet.

Reagan considered nuclear weapons to be totally irrational, and in a famous speech publicly implored the Soviet leader to tear it down:

General Secretary Gorbachev, if you seek peace, if you seek prosperity for the Soviet Union and Eastern Europe, if you seek liberalization: Come here to this gate! Mr. Gorbachev, open this gate! Mr. Gorbachev, tear down this wall!
 — Ronald Reagan, in his Berlin Wall Speech, given at the Brandenburg Gate, June 12, 1987. [The full speech is available on youtube.]

Of course, Ronald Reagan's speech was not the only thing to help bring about the end of the Berlin Wall. But it makes an excellent focal point for understanding the sentiment about the wall at that time.

Reagan's Part: Logic and Ideas

Although he was certainly a fan of the Founding Fathers, Ronald Reagan disagreed with Benjamin Franklin's sentiment, expressed in a Letter to Josiah Quincy dated September 11, 1783, that There never was a good war or a bad peace. Not only was Franklin's wisdom a relic of a time long before the possibility of mutually assured destruction, it might also imply a willingness to submit to the Soviet Empire's aggression, which was clearly unacceptable.

If Reagan was going to call for peace, it would be a peace on his terms — terms that would not compromise his patriotic ideals or any of the freedoms Americans had grown accustomed to over the nation's past 200+ years.

When Mikhail Gorbachev took charge of the Soviet Union in the 1980s, he introduced two important reforms: glasnost, which called for more openness and transparency in Soviet society and perestroika, which called for more freedom in the economy.

Reagan's part in this was to:

  • recognize that Gorbachev's reforms offered the opportunity to move past the previous administrations' policies of detente
  • visualize a space-based defensive system.
What if free people could live secure in the knowledge that their security did not rest upon the threat of instant U.S. retaliation to deter a Soviet attack, that we could intercept and destroy strategic ballistic missiles before they reached our own soil or that of our allies? I know this is a formidable, technical task, one that may not be accomplished before the end of this century.
 — From Ronald Reagan's Address to the Nation on Defense and National Security, March 23, 1983.

A Mixed Legacy

Ultimately contributed to end of cold war.

Administration was also marred by massive budget deficits and the beginning of escalating income inequality.
